just wondering if Vim has any multiple tab feature? allowing me to edit multiple docs at the same time

Tabs in vim are a bit different from the normal idea of tabs are not usually used for editing multiple buffers/files at the same time. You probably want something like minibufexplorer (http://www.vim.org/scripts/script.php?script_id=159) that displays a list of open buffers/files at the top of your screen.
You can use Tabs for separate workspaces in a single vim session. For example, on a new tab you can use the command :lcd to change the current working directory for the current tab.
@jb55 quick ques, newtr or NERDTree? and why

For quickly switching between buffers, you can use the :b command, which has smart tab autocompletion. You can also use NERDTree(http://www.vim.org/scripts/script.php?script_id=1658) for displaying a directory listing for the current working directory.
I've never used newtr, so I couldn't say

I may be among the minority that does this, but I set `let NERDTreeHijackNetrw = 0` -- I use NERDTree as a sidebar but I want netrw when I try to edit a directory. netrw is far more capable as a file manipulation tool. As always, check the excellent built-in help with `:help netrw`

Perhaps the best feature of netrw is (as the 'net' implies) is transparently browsing and editing remote files. `:e scp://someserver/somedirectory` and boom, you're browsing that directory over SSH and can open files for editing.
